source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_041_chunk4

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_041_chunk4
evidence_span: for Zr-2.5Nb and zirconium the percentages were low in both systems

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_041_chunk4
evidence_span: Percentages of hydrogen absorbed were consistently low on specimens having high weight gains

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_041_chunk6

evidence_span: slight flux enhancement on the Zircaloys

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_041_chunk6
evidence_span: Zirconium moved rapidly out of the pretransition regime in both oxygenated and deoxygenated environments

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_041_chunk6
evidence_span: Zr-2.5Nb exposed to oxygenated coolants at high-flux locations nucleated and devloped pustules in ETR and ATR environments

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_041_chunk6

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_041_chunk6
evidence_span: oxides with weight gains of 120 to $1 6 0 ~ \mathrm { m g / }$ $\mathbf { d } \mathbf { m } ^ { 2 }$ continue to be sensitive to environment

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_041_chunk7
evidence_span: When uranium was present in the water, the corrosion rate increased for pickled and for autoclaved fuel rods

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_041_chunk7
evidence_span: hardly any effect was observed with anodized material

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_041_chunk7
evidence_span: A deliberate fluoride contamination on the specimens increased the corrosion rate in-pile as well as out-of-pile

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_041_chunk7
evidence_span: By anodizing this harmful effect of fluorides could be completely counteracted
